reason: INCORRECT PROOF OF (Phi2): The justification that Phi_n(p) > 0 for n >= 2 claims 'each H_p(lambda_i) involves at least one nonzero term 1/(lambda_i - lambda_j), and the sum of squares of n real numbers, each being a nonempty sum of nonzero terms, is strictly positive.' This argument is WRONG because a nonempty sum of nonzero terms CAN equal zero. COUNTEREXAMPLE: For n=3 with roots at 0, 1, 2: H_p(1) = 1/(1-0) + 1/(1-2) = 1 + (-1) = 0. So H_p(lambda_i) can be zero for interior roots. The property Phi_n > 0 for n >= 2 IS TRUE, but requires a DIFFERENT argument: the extremal roots lambda_1 (smallest) and lambda_n (largest) always have H_p(lambda_1) = sum_{j>1} 1/(lambda_1 - lambda_j) < 0 (all terms negative) and H_p(lambda_n) > 0 (all terms positive), so Phi_n >= H_p(lambda_1)^2 + H_p(lambda_n)^2 > 0.
